CSS Custom Properties

--* and @property

Introduced by Firefox in July 2014,
and fully supported across browsers
since April 2017
(DOCS)

Centralizing values

      
:root {
  --primary-color: #3498db;
  --font-size-base: 16px;
}

body {
  color: var(--primary-color);
  font-size: var(--font-size-base);
}

Flowing with the cascade

      
:root {
  --primary-color: #3498db;
  --font-size-base: 16px;
}

body {
  --font-size-base: 18px;

  color: var(--primary-color);
  font-size: var(--font-size-base);
}

Dynamic and Conditional overrides...

      
:root {
  --background-color: #ffffff;
  --text-color: #000000;
}

@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
  --background-color: #000000;
  --text-color: #ffffff;
}

body {
  background-color: var(--background-color);
  color: var(--text-color);
}

...the same goes for Responsive

      
:root {
  --padding: 8px;
}

@media (min-width: 600px) {
  :root {
    --padding: 16px;
  }
}

.container {
  padding: var(--padding);
}

Javascript interaction

Common js "CRUD" operations with CSS custom properties

Reading a variable from an element

      
const button = document.querySelector('button');

// gets the "--primary-color" value
// from element's CSSStyleDeclaration

//! may be null if the variable is not defined on the element itself
button.style.getPropertyValue('--primary-color');

// gets the "--primary-color" value
// from the element's ComputedStyle, 
// so with inherited values too

//! may be an empty string if the variable is not defined on 
//! the element itself nor any of its ancestors
getComputedStyle(button).getPropertyValue('--primary-color');

Reading a variable from :root

      
const root = document.documentElement;

// gets the "--primary-color" value
// from the root element's ComputedStyle

//! may be an empty string if the variable is not defined
getComputedStyle(root).getPropertyValue('--primary-color');

Writing a variable to an element

      
const button = document.querySelector('button');

// sets the "--primary-color" value
// to the element's CSSStyleDeclaration
button.style.setProperty('--primary-color', '#e74c3c');

Writing a variable to :root

      
const root = document.documentElement;

// sets the "--primary-color" value 
// to the root element's CSSStyleDeclaration
root.style.setProperty('--primary-color', '#e74c3c');

Deleting a variable from an element

      
const button = document.querySelector('button');

// deletes the "--primary-color" variable
// from the element's CSSStyleDeclaration
button.style.removeProperty('--primary-color');

Deleting a variable from :root

      
const root = document.documentElement;

// deletes the "--primary-color" variable
// from the root element's CSSStyleDeclaration
root.style.removeProperty('--primary-color');

@property definition

and the CSS Properties and Values API

Introduced by Chrome in August 2020,
and fully supported across browsers
since July 2024
(@property DOCS)
(CSS Properties and Values API DOCS)

Registering a property via CSS

    
@property --coffee-color {
  syntax: "<color>";
  inherits: false;
  initial-value: #c0ffee;
}

Registering a property via JS

    
window.CSS.registerProperty({
  name: "--coffee-color",
  syntax: "<color>",
  inherits: false,
  initialValue: "#c0ffee",
});

What are the differences between registered and unregistered custom properties?

Registered properties are animatable and transitionable

    
<button class="unregistered">Background Not Registered</button>
<button class="registered">Background Registered</button>
    
  
    
button.unregistered {
  --unregistered--coffee-color: #c0ffee;
  background-color: var(--unregistered--coffee-color);
  transition: --unregistered--coffee-color 1s ease-in-out; // this will NOT work

  &:hover,  &:focus {
    --unregistered--coffee-color: #b4d455;
  }
}

button.registered {
  --coffee-color: #c0ffee;
  background-color: var(--coffee-color);
  transition: --coffee-color 1s ease-in-out; // this will work

  &:hover, &:focus {
    --coffee-color: #b4d455;
  }
}

Animations with registered properties

      
@property --intro--color--fade {
  initial-value: #b19cd8;
  inherits: false;
  syntax: '<color>';
}

:root {
  --intro--color--purple-400: #b19cd8;

  ...
  
  --intro--color--red-400: #e86a58;
}

Animations with registered properties

      
@keyframes intro {
  0% {
    --intro--color--fade: var(--intro--color--purple-400);
  }
  
  ...

  100% {
    --intro--color--fade: var(--intro--color--red-400);
  }
}

Animations with registered properties

        
h2 {
  --stagger--delay: 300ms;
  --stagger--index: 0;

  span {
    color: var(--intro--color--fade);
    animation: intro 5s linear calc(var(--stagger--delay) * var(--stagger--index)) infinite alternate;

    &:nth-child(1) { --stagger--index: 0; }
    &:nth-child(2) { --stagger--index: 1; } // u

    ... 
    
    &:nth-child(10) { --stagger--index: 9; }
    &:nth-child(11) { --stagger--index: 10; }
  }
}

CSS Layers

@layer

Introduced by Firefox in February 2022,
and fully supported across browsers
since March 2022
(DOCS)

CSS Layers Example

      
        
@layer reset {
  // https://css-tricks.com/css-remedy/        

  * {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    ...
  }
}

@layer components {
  button {
    border-size: 1px solid lightgray;
  }
}

@layer layout {
  body {
    display: grid;
    grid-template-areas:
      'header header'
      'aside main'
      'footer footer';
  }
}

Layers Order

      
@layer reset, layout, components;

Layers depths levels

      
@layer ui {
  @layer button {
    :root {
      --button--font-size: 18px;
    }

    button {
      font-size: var(--button--font-size);
    }
  }

  @layer input {
    :root {
      --input--font-size: 20px;
    }

    input {
      font-size: var(--input--font-size);
    }
  } 
}

Reverse Cascade

      
:root {
  --ui--font-size: 10px;
}
      
@layer ui {
  :root {
    --ui--font-size: 16px;
  }
 
  @layer button {
    :root {
      --ui--font-size: 18px;
    }

    button {
      font-size: var(--ui--font-size);
    }
  }

  @layer input {
    :root {
      --ui--font-size: 20px;
    }

    input {
      font-size: var(--ui--font-size);
    }
  }
}

What about old CSS codebase and third party dependencies?

The layer() function will be your best friend

@import ... layer() pattern

      
@import 'path-to-old-dependency.css' layer(old-library.old-dependency);
@import 'path-to-old-dependency.theme.css' layer(old-library.old-dependency);
@import 'path-to-other-old-dependency.css' layer(old-library.other-old-dependency);
        
@layer new-library {
  ...
}

CSS APIs approach

Let's "seed" a Design System codebase,
combining --* and @layer

Example Design System CSS APIs codebase (1/4)
reset layer 

        
@layer design-system {
  @layer reset {
    * {
      box-sizing: border-box;
      ...
    }
  }
  
  ...
}

Example Design System CSS APIs codebase (2/4)
color palette and elevations layers 

        
@layer design-system {
  ...
    
  @layer colors {
    :root {
      --ds--colors--dark: #202020;
      --ds--colors--light: #fefefe;

      --ds--colors--purple: #9f7aea;
      --ds--colors--cyan: #0bc5ea;
      --ds--colors--green: #48bb78;
      --ds--colors--yellow: #ecc94b;
      --ds--colors--red: #f56565;

      ...
    }
  }
    
  @layer elevations {
    :root {
      --ds--elevations--shadow-color-1: hsla(210, 3%, 36%, 0.16);
      --ds--elevations--shadow-color-2: hsla(213, 5%, 42%, 0.38);

      // Cards, etc...
      --ds--elevation-400: 0 1px 7px 1px var(--ds--elevation--shadow-color-1),
        0 1px 7px -1px var(--ds--elevation--shadow-color-2);

      // Tooltips, etc...
      --ds--elevation-500: 0 2px 4px -1px var(--ds--elevation--shadow-color-1),
        0 3px 12px -1px var(--ds--elevation--shadow-color-2);
  
      ...
    }
  }
}

Example Design System CSS APIs codebase (3/4)
typography and iconography layers 

        
@layer design-system {
  ...
    
  @layer typography {
    :root {
      --ds--typography--ratio: 1.125; // major second
      --ds--typography--font-family: Verdana;
      --ds--typography--font-size: 1.6rem;
      --ds--typography--font-weight: 400;
      --ds--typography--line-height: 1.3;
      
      ...
    }
    
    body {
      font-family: var(--ds--typography--font-family);
      font-size: var(--ds--typography--font-size);
      font-weight: var(--ds--typography--font-weight);
      line-height: var(--ds--typography--line-height);

      ...
    }
  }
  
  @layer iconography { /* iconography classes */ }
}

Example Design System CSS APIs codebase (4/4)
components layer 

        
@layer design-system {
  ...
  
  @layer components {
    :root {
      /* common components variables */
    }
    
    @layer button { /* buttons component variables and styles */ }
    @layer input { /* input component variables and styles */ }
    @layer select { /* select component variables and styles */ }
    
    ...
  }
}

That's it!
CSS APIs is ready to use

Every variable defined
in a layered :root {} selector
can be easily overridden into an un-layered :root {} selector

Example Overriding the Design System CSS APIs codebase

  ...
  
  @layer components {
    ...
  }
}

  --ds--colors--dark: #202020;

Case Studies

Case Study 1: Re-branding (1/3)

Re-branding is the process of redefining the identity of a product, company, or service to reflect a new vision, updated values, or a change in market positioning. This process may include:

Case Study 1: Re-branding (2/3)

  • Updating Logo and Aesthetics: New colors, typography, and visual styles
  • Redefining Tone of Voice: New language or communication to connect with a different audience
  • Renewed Positioning: Adapting the brand to attract new customer segments or respond to market changes
  • Revamping User Experience: Changing the design of the website, apps, and all visual touchpoints

Case Study 1: Re-branding (3/3)

Goal: Create a more modern perception in line with the target audience, increasing competitiveness and fostering an emotional connection with customers.

Case Study 2: Re-selling (1/3)

Re-selling is the process of selling an existing product to new customers or markets, adapting it to meet each customer's specific needs without creating a new product from scratch. This process may include:

Case Study 2: Re-selling (2/3)

  • Aesthetic Customization: Adapting colors, logo, and typography for new customers
  • Multi-Tenant Design: Making the product easily configurable for multiple customers without altering the main code
  • Scalability: Creating a product that is flexible and ready to be adapted efficiently for new customers
  • Code Reusability: Avoiding duplication and keeping the code modular to reduce implementation costs and time

Case Study 2: Re-selling (3/3)

Goal: Maximize the profitability of an existing product by adapting it for new sales while ensuring efficiency and maintainability.

Case Study 3: Multi-tenant (1/3)

Multi-tenant is a software architecture in which a single instance of an application serves multiple customers (tenants), maintaining data and customization separation for each one. Each customer shares the same codebase but sees the application as if it were a unique instance.

Case Study 3: Multi-tenant (2/3)

  • Resource Sharing: Infrastructure and resources are shared among tenants, reducing management costs
  • Customization for Each Tenant: Ability to apply branding and functionality customizations without modifying the main application
  • Operational Efficiency: Maintaining a single codebase makes updates easier and reduces maintenance time
  • Scalability and Security: Each tenant can be logically isolated to ensure security and scalability

Case Study 3: Multi-tenant (3/3)

Goal: Maximize operational efficiency and scalability, allowing each customer to have a personalized experience without compromising system centralization.

10 ways CSS APIs approach can help
1. Branding Update and Consistency
  • Applies to: Re-Branding
  • Problem: Need to update colors, fonts, and visual styles to reflect a new brand.
  • Solution: Use CSS Custom Properties to centralize colors and typography. A root-level update allows for a quick and consistent change throughout the product.
2. Customization for Different Clients
  • Applies to: Re-selling & Multi-Tenant
  • Problem: Adapting the product for different clients with distinct branding needs.
  • Solution: Easily override CSS Custom Properties for each client or tenant (e.g., using attributes like `data-tenant`) to manage colors, fonts, and styles without duplicating code.
3. Single Codebase Maintenance
  • Applies to: Re-selling & Multi-Tenant
  • Problem: Duplicating the codebase for different clients can be inefficient and difficult to maintain.
  • Solution: Use CSS Custom Properties to customize the product and CSS Layers to separate base styles from styles specific to each client.
4. Reducing Technical Debt
  • Applies to: All the three case studies
  • Problem: High specificity and style duplication.
  • Solution: Use CSS Layers to separate base layers, themes, and tenant-specific styles. CSS Custom Properties centralize values, reducing the need for repetition and facilitating maintainability.
5. Handling Specificity Conflicts
  • Applies to: Re-branding & Multi-Tenant
  • Problem: Overlapping styles causing conflicts during customizations.
  • Solution: With CSS Layers, you can control the order of style application, ensuring correct precedence without increasing specificity.
6. Support for Dynamic Theming
  • Applies to: Re-selling & Multi-Tenant
  • Problem: Differentiating themes for various clients efficiently.
  • Solution: CSS Custom Properties allow for dynamic theming by simply varying global properties for each client, making the process simple and scalable.
7. Scalability
  • Applies to: All the three case studies
  • Problem: Applying branding and style changes uniformly.
  • Solution: Thanks to CSS Custom Properties, a central change in color, typography, or spacing immediately reflects across the application, maintaining a cleaner and more maintainable codebase.
8. Responsive Design for Different Clients
  • Applies to: Re-selling & Multi-Tenant
  • Problem: Adapting layout and breakpoints to different client preferences.
  • Solution: Define breakpoints with CSS Custom Properties, making it possible to personalize breakpoints for different clients without duplicating media queries.
9. Gradual Transition from Old to New
  • Applies to: Re-branding
  • Problem: Implementing the new brand without drastically impacting user experience during the transition.
  • Solution: CSS Layers allow you to keep old rules in a separate layer while progressively implementing the new design, ensuring a smoother and safer transition.
10. Optimization of Testing
  • Applies to: All the three case studies
  • Problem: Ensuring that every part of the UI is updated correctly and that all customizations are consistent.
  • Solution: CSS Custom Properties centralize values, making changes easier to control and reducing the risk of inconsistencies. CSS Layers keep client-specific updates separate, minimizing conflicts and simplifying testing.

Wrapping up

CSS Custom Properties and CSS Layers are fundamental tools for effectively addressing the needs of re-branding, re-selling, and multi-tenant.

Pros

  • Proactive Strategy
  • Efficiency
  • Modularity
  • Maintainability
  • Progressive Enhancement
  • Visual Bug Hunting time reduction

Cons

  • Learning & Practice Curve
  • Bootstrapping projects initially more complex
  • Minimum impact on performances

Conclusions

  • Over-engineering as strategic investment
  • Being prepared to future evolutions of CSS
  • Invite to Action: Experiment & Share
